abstracts.cdata!:
This executive summary is aimed at
            presenting the main findings of the Environmental Assessment
            conducted for the Iran Water Supply and Sanitation Project.
            Ahwuz, the capital of Khouzestan province is one of the most
            important economical centers of Iran, located in an oil-rich
            region and hosts a number of large industries. Areas without
            wastewater either use seepage pits, or discharge their
            wastewater in open channels, rivers or in open grounds,
            creating wastewater pools, polluting the soil and water
            resources, and creating health hazards. The Karoun River
            flows along Ahwaz and divides the city into two separate
            drainage zones: the eastern zone and the western zone.
            Therefore, pollution of the Karoun River is a major problem,
            and a priority issue not only for Ahwaz, but for the whole
            province, for the poor water quality is largely contributing
            to high diarrhea prevalence that reaches. Similar to Ahwuz,
            wastewater collection, treatment and disposal are the main
            environmental concern in Shiraz. Although the proposed
            project will reduce the pollution loads discharged to the
            Karoun River and Maharloo lake, it will not solve the
            pollution problem of these two water bodies, primarily due
            to agricultural drainage and industrial discharges. This
            Environmental Assessment summarizes the policy and legal
            requirements, as well as Bank safeguard policies. Mitigation
            measures are as follows. To reduce noise disturbances, work
            should be restricted to normal working hours; equipment with
            appropriate silencers should be used, only run when
            required. Dust suppression measures should be employed, such
            as spraying and dust enclosures, to minimize air pollution.
            Movement of construction vehicles should be restricted to,
            and from the sites during normal working hours; traffic
            diverted through suitable roads to the expected traffic
            loading; adequate traffic signals should be in place; and,
            expeditious completion of backfill, and reinstatement
            completed. The application of protection measures in areas
            close to existing historical sites should be ensured.
            Wastes, demolition and excavated materials should be
            collected, and disposed of at appropriate locations, while
            surface runoff from the site should be restricted. Moreover,
            wastes generated during construction should be minimized, by
            reusing construction wastes where practicable, and,
            appropriate methods for the storage of waste materials
            should be conducted. To mitigate the degradation of water
            quality, the operation and maintenance of the water
            treatment plant shall be ensured, as well as the continuous
            monitoring of raw water, and treated water, including water
            quality at various locations within the water supply system,
            avoiding cross contamination with sewage. Adequate treatment
            (retention time) should be provided to control the number of
            nematode eggs, in addition, chlorine should be used to
            disinfect the effluent, and for Ahwaz nitrification and
            de-nitrification to control concentration of nitrogen.
            Regular monitoring of treated effluent, which shall not be
            discharged in the Karoun river, nor re-used in irrigation if
            its quality does not meet the standards. Capacity building,
            training and awareness will be supported to comply with
            environmental standards and guidelines.
